ITPγS and XTPγS were synthesized by nucleoside diphosphokinase-catalyzed transthiophosphorylation as described previously (21Goody R.S. Eckstein F. Schirmer R.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1972; 276: 155-161Google Scholar), with modifications. Briefly, reaction mixtures contained 10 mm IDP or XDP and 5 mmadenosine 5′-[γ-thio]triphosphate in 30 mm Tris/HCl, pH 8.0, supplemented with 5.0 mm dithiothreitol and 5.0 mm MgCl2 in a total volume of 1.0 ml. The reaction was initiated by the addition of 78 IU nucleoside diphosphokinase and conducted at 37 °C for 24–48 h until the reaction equilibrium resulted in maximum NTPγS product. The product NTPγS was then purified by fast protein liquid chromatography mono Q ion-exchange chromatography using either a 30 min linear gradient from 0.1–2 m ammonium acetate, pH >8.0, or by isocratic elution in the same buffer (the gradient method allowed the recovery of starting IDP/XDP). The collected product peak was lyophilized and, if necessary, repurified using a shallow gradient. The final product was analyzed for purity by both isocratic and gradient elution from the same chromatography systems used for the purification. The pH > 8.0 ammonium acetate purification buffer produced synthetic NTPγS of >98% purity based on fast protein liquid chromatography elution. At lower pH, the product was a mixture of NTPγS and IDP/XDP at a ratio of >88:12. Purified products contained 0.75–1.2 μmol of NTPγS as assessed by UV absorption at λmax relative to IDP/XDP standard. cDNAs for Gαs mutants were generated by overlap extension PCR (22Seifert R. Wenzel-Seifert K. Lee T.W. Gether U. Sanders-Bush E. Kobilka B.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 5109-5116Google Scholar, 23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar) using pGEM-3Z-β2AR-GαsL as template. Sense and antisense primers encoding for the Q227L mutation (L227) created a diagnostic BanII site; sense and antisense primers encoding for the D295N mutation (N295) resulted in the loss of aBglII site. For generation of GαsL-L227/N295 cDNA, pGEM-β2AR-GαsL-L227 served as template, using the primers for generation of the D295N mutation. Recombinant pGEM-3Z-β2AR-GαsL plasmids were digested with EcoRI and XbaI and cloned into pVL1392-β2AR-GαsL digested withEcoRI and XbaI. To generate the corresponding GαsS cDNAs, the NheI/EcoRI fragment of pGEM-3Z-β2AR-GαsS replaced theNheI/EcoRI fragment of pGEM-3Z-β2AR-GαsL mutants. For generation of pVL1392-Gαs plasmids devoid of β2AR cDNA, pVL1392-β2AR-Gαs plasmids were digested with SacI and PflMI to eliminate β2AR cDNA. The noncoherent DNA ends were filled with Klenow fragment, and the pVL1392-Gαs plasmids were religated. Extensive restriction enzyme diagnostics and enzymatic sequencing confirmed all mutations. Sf9 cells were cultured in 250-ml disposable Erlenmeyer flasks at 28 °C under shaking at 125 rpm in SF 900 II medium (Invitrogen). Recombinant baculoviruses were generated in Sf9 cells using the BaculoGOLD transfection kit (Pharmingen) as described previously (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). For protein expression, Sf9 cells were infected with 1:100 dilutions of high titer baculovirus stocks and cultured for 48 h (17Seifert R. Lee T.W. Lam V.T. Kobilka B.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 255: 369-382Google Scholar). Sf9 membranes were prepared as described previously (17Seifert R. Lee T.W. Lam V.T. Kobilka B.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 255: 369-382Google Scholar). Membranes were suspended in binding buffer (12.5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, and 75 mm Tris/HCl, pH 7.4) at a concentration of ∼1–2 mg protein/ml and stored at −80 °C until use. Expression levels of β2AR-Gαs fusion proteins were determined by [3H]dihydroalprenolol saturation binding (17Seifert R. Lee T.W. Lam V.T. Kobilka B.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 255: 369-382Google Scholar). Immediately before AC and NTPase experiments, membrane aliquots were thawed and centrifuged for 15 min at 4 °C and 15,000 × g to remove, as far as possible, endogenous nucleotides (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). The determination of AC activity in Sf9 membranes was performed as described previously (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). Briefly, tubes (30 μl) contained membranes (20–40 μg protein/tube), 5 mm MgCl2, 0.4 mm EDTA, 30 mm Tris/HCl, pH 7.4, and nucleotides at various concentrations. Some experiments were conducted in the presence of ISO or ICI 118,551. Tubes were incubated for 3 min at 37 °C before the addition of 20 μl of reaction mixture containing (final) [α-32P]ATP (0.5–1.5 μCi/tube) plus 40 μm ATP, 2.7 mm mono(cyclohexyl)ammonium phosphoenolpyruvate, 0.125 IU pyruvate kinase, 1.0 IU myokinase, and 0.1 mm cAMP. Reactions were conducted for 20 min. Stopping of reactions and separation of [α-32P]ATP from [32P]cAMP were performed as described previously (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). In some experiments, the incubation temperature was varied from 16–37 °C. High-affinity GTPase activity in Sf9 membranes expressing β2AR-Gαs fusion proteins was determined as described previously (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). Briefly, tubes (80 μl) contained membranes (10 μg protein/tube), 1.0 mm MgCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, 0.1 mm ATP, 1 mm adenosine 5′-[β,γ-imido]triphosphate, 5 mm creatine phosphate, 40 μg creatine kinase, 30 nm to 10 μmunlabeled GTP, 10 μm ISO, and 0.05% (w/v) bovine serum albumin in 50 mm Tris/HCl, pH 7.4. Reaction mixtures were incubated for 3 min at 25 °C before the addition of 20 μl of [γ-32P]GTP (2.0 μCi/tube). Nonenzymatic [γ-32P]GTP hydrolysis was determined in the presence of a large excess of unlabeled GTP (1 mm) and amounted to <1% of total [γ-32P]GTP hydrolysis. Reactions were conducted for 20 min. Stopping of reactions and recovery of [32P]Pi were performed as described previously (23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). XTPase activity was determined as GTPase activity, except that XTP and [γ-32P]XTP were used. Membrane proteins were separated on SDS-polyacrylamide gels containing 10% (w/v) acrylamide. Proteins were transferred onto Immobilon-P transfer membranes (Millipore, Bedford, MA). Membranes were reacted with anti-Gαs Ig or anti-FLAG Ig (1:1000 each). Immunoreactive bands were visualized by donkey anti-rabbit IgG (anti-Gαs Ig) or sheep anti-mouse IgG (anti-FLAG Ig) coupled to peroxidase at 1:1000 dilutions, usingo-dianisidine and H2O2 as substrates. Immunoblots were scanned using a Molecular Imager FX and evaluated with the Quantity One 4.3 software (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA), using β2AR-Gαs fusion proteins (25–75 μg/lane) expressed at defined levels ([3H]dihydroalprenolol saturation binding) as standard. Protein concentrations were determined with the Bio-Rad DC protein assay kit (Bio-Rad). Data shown in Figs. AC activity in Sf9 membranes was determined as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Reaction mixtures contained Sf9 membranes (20–40 μg protein/tube) expressing GαsL (A,E, and I), GαsL-N295 (B,F, and J), GαsL-L227/N295 (C, G, and K), or GαsL-L227 (D, H, and L) in the presence of NTPs (A–D), NTPγSs (E–H), or NppNHps (I–L) at the concentrations indicated on theabscissa. Data shown are the means ± S.D. of three to six experiments performed in duplicates.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) In mammalian cells, GαsS and GαsL possess apparent molecular masses of 45 and 52 kDa, respectively (24Walseth T.F. Zhang H.J. Olson L.K. Schroeder W.A. Robertson R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 21106-21111Google Scholar, 25Jones D.T. Masters S.B. Bourne H.R. Reed R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 2671-2676Google Scholar, 26O'Donnell J. Sweet R.W. Stadel J.M. Mol. Pharmacol. 1991; 39: 702-710Google Scholar). The same was true for GαsS and GαsL expressed in Sf9 membranes (Fig.1 A). In agreement with a recent report (27Kühn B. Christel C. Wieland T. Schultz G. Gudermann T. Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Arch. Pharmacol. 2002; 365: 231-241Google Scholar), GαsL expressed in Sf9 membranes also showed a ∼40-kDa proteolytic fragment. In contrast, GαsS did not exhibit major proteolytic fragments. However, in membranes expressing GαsS-L212, GαsS-N280, and GαsS-L212/N280, a prominent ∼39-kDa proteolytic fragment became apparent (Fig. 1 B). In membranes expressing the corresponding GαsL mutants, the ∼40-kDa fragment was present, and an additional ∼46-kDa proteolytic fragment emerged. These data indicate that Gαs and Gαs mutants possess different conformations,i.e. proteases access Gαs mutants more readily than Gαs. Gαs and Gαs mutants were expressed at similar levels (9–15 pmol/mg). We also expressed β2AR-Gαs fusion proteins. Fusion proteins allow for the sensitive analysis of β2AR/Gαs coupling, particularly with respect to NTP hydrolysis (17Seifert R. Lee T.W. Lam V.T. Kobilka B.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 255: 369-382Google Scholar, 18Seifert R. Gether U. Wenzel-Seifert K. Kobilka B.K. Mol. Pharmacol. 1999; 56: 348-358Google Scholar). β2AR-GαsS and β2AR-GαsL proteins exhibited the expected molecular masses of ∼100 and 106 kDa, respectively (Fig.1 C) (22Seifert R. Wenzel-Seifert K. Lee T.W. Gether U. Sanders-Bush E. Kobilka B.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 5109-5116Google Scholar). The expression levels of β2AR-Gαs proteins ranged between 4 and 7 pmol/mg. Collectively, Gαs and Gαs mutants in the nonfused and fused state were expressed at similar levels in Sf9 membranes. For brevity, we only show the AC data with nonfused Gαs. Studies with β2AR-Gαs proteins yielded essentially the same results. GTP, ITP, and XTP were essentially devoid of stimulatory effects on AC in membranes expressing GαsL, GαsL-N295, and GαsL-L227 (Fig. 2,A, B, and D). A striking difference among those three constructs was the extremely high basal AC activity in the absence of GTP, ITP, or XTP in membranes expressing GαsL-L227. This finding could be explained by the GTPase deficiency brought about by the Gln/Leu mutation (14Graziano M.P. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15475-15482Google Scholar, 15Masters S.B. Miller R.T. Chi M.H. Chang F.H. Beiderman B. Lopez N.G. Bourne H.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15467-15474Google Scholar). However, the Gln/Leu mutation also increases the GDP affinity of GαsL(14Graziano M.P. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15475-15482Google Scholar, 15Masters S.B. Miller R.T. Chi M.H. Chang F.H. Beiderman B. Lopez N.G. Bourne H.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15467-15474Google Scholar), and Gαs-GDP activates AC as efficiently as Gαs-GTPγS, provided that the concentration of Gαs-GDP is sufficiently high (28Sunahara R.K. Dessauer C.W. Whisnant R.E. Kleuss C. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 22265-22271Google Scholar). As will be shown at the end of “Results,” the β2AR agonist ISO efficiently reduces AC activity in the absence of GTP in membranes co-expressing the β2AR plus GαsL-L227/N295 through GDP dissociation and generation of nucleotide-free Gαs. Nucleotide-free Gαs is less efficient at activating AC than Gαs-GDP (22Seifert R. Wenzel-Seifert K. Lee T.W. Gether U. Sanders-Bush E. Kobilka B.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 5109-5116Google Scholar, 23Liu H.-Y. Wenzel-Seifert K. Seifert R. J. Neurochem. 2001; 78: 325-338Google Scholar). These data indicate that the increase in GDP affinity induced by the Gln/Leu mutation critically contributes to the high basal AC activity in membranes expressing such mutants. GαsL-N295 and GαsL-L227/N295 were expected to possess decreased GDP affinity (5Yu B. Slepak V.Z. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18015-18019Google Scholar, 12Yu B. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30183-30188Google Scholar, 13Yu B. Gu L. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 71-76Google Scholar) and basal AC activity relative to GαsL and GαsL-L227, respectively. The experimental data were in agreement with these assumptions (Fig. 2, A–D). In contrast to membranes expressing GαsL and GαsL-N295, NTPs significantly increased AC activity in membranes expressing GαsL-L227/N295, compatible with a reduction of NTPase activity of GαsL-L227/N295 (14Graziano M.P. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15475-15482Google Scholar, 15Masters S.B. Miller R.T. Chi M.H. Chang F.H. Beiderman B. Lopez N.G. Bourne H.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 15467-15474Google Scholar). In fact, ISO had virtually no stimulatory effect on GTP and XTP hydrolysis in membranes expressing β2AR-GαsL-L227/N295 (data not shown). In agreement with data for the rab5-N136 mutant (29Hoffenberg S. Nikolova L. Pan J.Y. Daniel D.S. Wessling-Resnick M. Knoll B.J. Dickey B.F. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 215: 241-249Google Scholar), the order of potency of NTPs at GαsL-L227/N295 was XTP > GTP > ITP. In membranes expressing GαsL, NTPγSs stimulated AC activity in the expected order of potency, GTPγS > ITPγS > XTPγS (Fig. 2 E) (18Seifert R. Gether U. Wenzel-Seifert K. Kobilka B.K. Mol. Pharmacol. 1999; 56: 348-358Google Scholar, 29Hoffenberg S. Nikolova L. Pan J.Y. Daniel D.S. Wessling-Resnick M. Knoll B.J. Dickey B.F. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 215: 241-249Google Scholar). In membranes expressing GαsL-N295, the order of potency was XTPγS > ITPγS > GTPγS, but the maximum AC activities in those membranes amounted to only ∼20% of the AC activities in membranes expressing GαsL. These data indicate that GαsL-N295, despite its efficient expression in Sf9 membranes (Fig. 1 B), exhibited only low functional activity. Routinely, we conducted AC assays at 37 °C. Intriguingly, the GαsL-A366S mutant, which, like GαsL-N295, possesses lower GDP affinity than GαsL, denatures at 37 °C and requires temperatures of <33 °C to be active (30Iiri T. Herzmark P. Nakamoto J.M. van Dop C. Bourne H.R. Nature. 1994; 371: 164-168Google Scholar). Therefore, we varied the incubation temperature in the AC assay from 16 °C to 37 °C, but these maneuvers did not increase AC activation by GαsL-N295 (data not shown). These data indicate that GαsL-N295 was largely expressed as a functionally inactive protein, although the incubation temperature of Sf9 cells was rather low (28 °C). The poor activity of GαsL-N295 is reminiscent of the properties of the analogous Asp/Asn mutants of Gαo, Gα11, and Gα16 (5Yu B. Slepak V.Z. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18015-18019Google Scholar, 12Yu B. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30183-30188Google Scholar, 13Yu B. Gu L. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 71-76Google Scholar). In Gαo, Gα11, and Gα16 Asp/Asn mutants, the additional Gln/Leu mutation resulted in XTPγS-selective Gα mutants (5Yu B. Slepak V.Z. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18015-18019Google Scholar, 12Yu B. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30183-30188Google Scholar, 13Yu B. Gu L. Simon M.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 71-76Google Scholar). However, the switch in base selectivity in GαsL-L227/N295 was incomplete, i.e. GTPγS, ITPγS, and XTPγS were similarly potent (Fig. 2 G). In membranes expressing GαsL-L227, NTPγSs were similarly potent at moderately reducing AC activity (Fig.2 H). In agreement with the NTPγS data, the order of potency of NppNHps at activating AC in membranes expressing GαsL was GppNHp > IppNHp > XppNHp, but the potencies of NppNHps were lower than the potencies of the corresponding NTPγSs (Fig. 2,E and I). In membranes expressing GαsL-N295, NppNHps stimulated AC in the order of potency XppNHp > GppNHp > IppNHp, but again, maximum AC activities were very low (Fig. 2 J). XppNHp increased AC activity in membranes expressing GαsL-L227/N295 with ∼10-fold higher potency than GppNHp (Fig. 2 K). These data fit to the data obtained with XTP/GTP (∼20-fold potency difference) (Fig. 2 C). IppNHp was virtually inactive in membranes expressing GαsL-L227/N295 (Fig. 2 K). In contrast to NTPγSs, NppNHps had only minimal inhibitory effects on AC activity in membranes expressing GαsL-L227 (Fig. 2,H and L). There were no notable differences in the effects of NTPs, NTPγSs, and NppNHps at GαsS and GαsS-L212 relative to the corresponding GαsL constructs, except that AC inhibition by NTPγSs in membranes expressing GαsS-L212 was only marginal (Figs. 2 H and3 H). Compared with membranes expressing GαsS, basal AC activity in membranes expressing GαsS-N280 was lower, indicative for the reduction in GDP affinity of the GαsS mutant (Fig. 3,E and F).
